parts: Can you analyze PEPCO Commercial electricity prices in the District of Columbia over the last 15 years and project out another 10 years?  Are there any approved rate increases happening over the next few years?

### Pepco DC Prices Set to Increase Dramatically This Summer

Apr 19, 2023

### Commercial customers should expect a significant price increase.

[Image 2]

In March, Pepco DC announced their new rates for 2023-2024. Starting June First, most Pepco DC commercial customers will see prices at least 66% higher than last year. The chart above details these price increases.

You can avoid paying these high rates by shopping for your energy supply. Shopping for your supply allows you to get custom pricing that has ben tailored to your specific energy needs., and guarantees that price for as long as five years.

Contact us today to start shopping and prevent this significant increase in your business's operating expenses.

Utilities > Electric > Electricity Standard Offer Service (SOS) Rates

* * *

# Electricity Standard Offer Service (SOS) Rates 

[Image 2: Electricity Standard Offer Service (SOS) Rates]

Electricity rate in D.C. to rise for most starting summer 2024  
Pepco's Standard Offer Service (SOS) rate for electricity generation in the District of Columbia will 【76†increase】 starting June 1, 2024. Consumers will likely see a significant increase on their monthly bill after this date. An average residential customer’s bill is projected to increase by 8%, or $8.12 per month.  

Eligible District residents can apply to several assistance or discount programs to help lower their utility costs and get 【77†tips for preparing their homes for high temperatures and summer storms】. 

【53†Utility discount programs, bill credits, and other assistance】

Please 【78†contact the DCPSC】 if you have any questions or need additional assistance.

What is a Standard Offer Service (SOS) electricity rate?  
Standard Offer Service, commonly referred to as SOS, is the “default” electricity supply service sold by electric utility companies to a utility customer who does not choose an 【79†alternative electricity supplier†dcpowerconnect.com】. In the District, Pepco is the SOS administrator and purchases electricity and sells it to consumers at an approved rate. The SOS program is administered under rules established by the Commission.  

Pepco and other SOS administrators purchase electricity during annual wholesale auctions. Several wholesale electricity suppliers place competitive bids to try to win contracts to supply electricity to an electric utility. The electric utility awards the contract to the wholesale supplier who made the lowest bid. Pepco 【80†states†www.pepco.com】 that these annual competitive auctions “provide customers with generation rates that are reflective of market conditions while at the same time providing protection against extreme conditions.”  

In the District, SOS rates have decreased from the previous year 50% of the time since 2006.  

Understand your electricity bill  
Most energy customers only look at their energy bill to find out what they need to pay each month. However, a utility bill is broken down into several different sections, each of which provides important information. 

【81†A guide to understanding your utility bill†dcpowerconnect.com】

Stay informed  
Residents can become more familiar with their energy options by gaining a deeper understanding of the 【82†many ways to

【46†Home】 » Pepco to increase rates over next three years

    Posted in【1†Government News】

#  Pepco to increase rates over next three years 

Public Service Commission approved $52M increase in split vote 

[Image 2] by 【51†Steve Bohnel】 July 8, 2021 11:07 am July 8, 2021 11:10 am

### Share this:

  * 【52†Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window)】
  * 【53†Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window)】
  * Click to email a link to a friend (Opens in new window)
  * 

[Image 3]   

Pepco, which has about 330,000 customers across Montgomery County, can increase its service rates over a three-year period, the state’s Public Service Commission has ruled. 

The PSC — the state’s regulatory body overseeing public utility rates and projects — 【54†issued a nearly 300-page order last week†www.scribd.com】 that granted Pepco a $52.2 million rate increase statewide over three years. 

At the end of that period, rates will have increased by about $5.20 a month. 

Benjamin Armstrong, a spokesman for Pepco, said in an interview that there will be no rate increases for the rest of this year, then a planned average $3.66 monthly increase in 2022 and another $1.54 monthly increase in 2023, leading to a total final monthly increase of $5.20. 

Pepco, which also serves Prince George’s County in Maryland, was asking for $110 million in rate increases. The utility said the increases at that level would help pay to improve service and for other capital projects, like substations and replacing lines and poles across Maryland. 

## 【55†Reading up on the candidates before you vote? Contribute now to support our reporting.†moco360.fundjournalism.org】

More specifically, the money would have been used: 

Advertisement 

  * to repair and replace more than 60,000 streetlights to be LED lights
  * for critical infrastructure near and at substations to improve performance and backup power
  * for 69kV transmission systems, which distribute power to substations.

Pepco’s multiyear plan also included improvements to three substations, including one in North Bethesda and another in Silver Spring. 

In a 3-2 vote, the PSC denied the $110 million request, but agreed to allow $52.2 million in increases. 

## 【56†Police investigate death of boy, 3, found in Rockville pool】

According to the order, PSC Chairman Jason Stanek and Commissioner Michael T. Richard agreed that some increase should be permitted and voted yes to the lower amount. 

Advertisement 

But they said Pepco should have done a better job in forecasting its future costs associated with improvements to its service and other capital projects. 

## 【24†Want more political and government news? Subscribe to MoCo360 Politics Briefing.】

Commissioner Anthony J. O’Donnell was the third vote to approve the increase. 

Commissioners Odogwu Obi Linton and Mindy L. Herman voted no. They said their concerns about Pepco’s forecasts and overall transparency during the process meant they couldn’t support a large increase in utility rates. 

Advertisement 

The Maryland Office of People’s Counsel, which represents residential customers in Public Service Commission cases, agreed with Linton and Herman. 

Armstrong said Pepco officials are still reviewing the PSC’s order, but much of the rate increases “are going right back into the system,” which has improved in overall reliability over roughly the last decade. The utility is still determining which projects to consider since the full request wasn’t funded, he said. 

The Office of People’s Counsel said in a press release that the PSC “denied accelerated recovery of several high-price distribution substation projects, totaling more than $56 million.” 

Advertisement 

The PSC also denied Pepco’s streetlight conversion project, according to the Office of People’s Counsel. 

During the past 10 years, “ongoing investments in the local energy grid have driven a 68 percent decrease in the frequency of electric outages Pepco customers have experienced” across Maryland and Washington, D
content.title: Pepco to increase electricity rates over next three years

parts:
Analyzing PEPCO commercial electricity prices in the District of Columbia over the last 15 years shows a trend of periodic increases and adjustments reflective of market conditions and regulatory decisions. Historical data from the District of Columbia Public Service Commission (DCPSC) reveals that Pepco's Standard Offer Service (SOS) rates for electricity have seen fluctuations, with a mix of rate hikes and reductions over this period. Notably, Pepco announced significant price increases for 2023-2024, with commercial customers expected to see their rates jump by at least 66% compared to the previous year【6†source】【7†source】.

Future projections for the next ten years indicate that commercial electricity rates will likely continue to rise. The DCPSC has approved a multi-year rate plan for Pepco, authorizing the utility to recover $108.6 million through higher rates, translating to continued increases in electricity costs for consumers【8†source】【9†source】.

In terms of approved rate increases over the next few years, the DCPSC has already sanctioned a structured increase in Pepco's rates. These adjustments are part of a broader plan to enhance service reliability and fund critical infrastructure projects. For instance, there are planned average monthly increases of $3.66 in 2022 and another $1.54 in 2023【9†source】.

For a detailed and up-to-date understanding of current and future electricity rates, it is advisable to refer to the DCPSC's official releases and Pepco's announcements, as they provide comprehensive insights into approved rate changes and the factors influencing them.
